importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date when the article was updated, indicating recent developments in the NYC mayoral race involving Curtis Sliwa, John Catsimatidis, Andrew Cuomo, and Zohran Mamdani.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The period during which key developments occurred, including Catsimatidis’s public call for Sliwa to drop out, Sliwa’s rebuttal on YouTube, Trump’s comments, and the growing tension between Republican figures and the Democratic nominee.

keyTakeAways: Curtis Sliwa, a Republican candidate for NYC mayor, is facing pressure to exit the race from his boss John Catsimatidis, who owns WABC radio and publicly urged him to withdraw, citing loyalty to New York City.
John Catsimatidis, a lifelong New Yorker and supermarket magnate, is attempting to unify Republican opposition to the Democratic nominee Zohran Mamdani by pushing Sliwa out of the race.
Andrew Cuomo, running as an independent, is actively rallying Republican voters and criticizing Sliwa as not a viable alternative, claiming he represents the same ideology as Mamdani.
Sliwa has defended his candidacy, rejecting claims that he lacks legitimacy and asserting that he represents blue-collar, working-class New Yorkers, not billionaire donors.
Trump dismissed Sliwa as 'not exactly primetime' and mocked his interest in animal rescues, signaling broader Republican skepticism of Sliwa’s viability.
Zohran Mamdani, the Democratic nominee, has dismissed allegations of coordination with Sliwa, emphasizing that New Yorkers should decide the future of the city, not elite donors or political figures.
Sliwa, known for founding the Guardian Angels and running in 2021 without holding office, is polling third in the mayoral race behind Mamdani and Cuomo.
The back-and-forth between Sliwa, Cuomo, and Mamdani highlights a growing ideological and strategic rift within the Republican party regarding how to oppose the Democratic socialist candidate.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Republican candidate Curtis Sliwa, known for founding the Guardian Angels and running in 2021, is under growing pressure to withdraw from the New York City mayoral race. This pressure comes directly from his boss, John Catsimatidis, who owns WABC radio and publicly urged Sliwa to step down, claiming he should love New York more than anything else. The broader Republican effort to oppose the Democratic nominee Zohran Mamdani has led to strong appeals from Andrew Cuomo, who runs as an independent and dismisses Sliwa as not viable, comparing him to Mamdani ideologically. Sliwa has publicly rejected these claims, emphasizing his connection to blue-collar working-class voters and criticizing billionaire donors like Bill Ackman and Andrew Cuomo, who he claims are determining the outcome of the race. President Donald Trump mocked Sliwa’s affinity for cats and animal rescues, further signaling Republican disinterest. Despite the pressure, Sliwa has doubled down on his candidacy, asserting that voters should have the final say, and Mamdani has dismissed rumors of coordination between the two candidates, both calling for New Yorkers to make the decision independently of elite influence.
title: Curtis Sliwa’s boss becomes the latest Republican trying to push him out of NYC mayoral race
